fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \exists _{\pi _{2}}(m, n) &\cong \mathsf {Img}(\pi _{2}(m,n))\\ &\cong \mathsf {Img}(n)\\ &\cong \exists _{\pi _{2}}((f,u_{1}) \cup (g,u_{2}))\\ &\cong \exists _{\pi _{2}}(f,u_{1}) \cup \exists _{\pi _{2}}(g,u_{2})\\ &\cong \mathsf {Img}(\pi _{2}(f,u_{1})) \cup \mathsf {Img}(\pi _{2}(g,u_{2}))\\ &\cong u_{1} \cup u_{2}\\ &\cong \mathsf {id}_{A_{1} \cup A_{2}} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, if n is monic then \mathsf {Img}(n) \cong n \cong \mathsf {id}_{A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, i.e., n is the whole of A_{1} \cup A_{2}, so it is an isomorphism. Let a,b\colon V\rightrightarrows U be a pair of morphisms such that na = nb. To show that a = b, it suffices to show ma = mb since n and m are jointly monic. To this end, we show that the equalizer of ma and mb is an isomorphism.
The object U (when viewed as the maximal subobject in \mathsf {Sub}(U)) is the union of the coproduct injections \ell and k.
The pullback of \ell \cup k along a or b are the maximal subobject of V since isomorphisms are stable under pullback. Thus, we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: V \cong a^{*}(\ell \cup k) \cong b^{*}(\ell \cup k)
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since finite unions are stable under pullback in a coherent category, we also have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: V \cong a^{*}(\ell ) \cup a^{*}(k) \cong b^{*}(\ell ) \cup b^{*}(k)
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, we can decompose V as the union of 4 subobjects using .
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} V \cong V \cap V &\cong (a^{*}(\ell ) \cup a^{*}(k)) \cap (b^{*}(\ell ) \cup b^{*}(k))\\ &\cong ((a^{*}(\ell ) \cup a^{*}(k)) \cap b^{*}(\ell )) \cup ((a^{*}(\ell ) \cup a^{*}(k)) \cap b^{*}(k))\\ &\cong (a^{*}(\ell ) \cap b^{*}(\ell )) \cup (a^{*}(\ell ) \cap b^{*}(k)) \cup (a^{*}(k) \cap b^{*}(\ell )) \cup (a^{*}(k) \cap b^{*}(k)) \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail V be the equalizer of ma and mb. To show that it is an isomorphism, it suffices to show that each of the 4 subobjects is contained in e, i.e., each of the 4 subobjects equalizes ma and mb. Let \ell ', \ell '', k', and k'' be given as follows:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1}'}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {\ell '}, south = a, west = {a^{*}(\ell )}, west/style = {>->}, east = \ell , east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1}''}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {\ell ''}, south = b, west = {b^{*}(\ell )}, west/style = {>->}, east = \ell , east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{2}'}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {k'}, south = a, west = {a^{*}(k)}, west/style = {>->}, east = k, east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{2}''}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {k''}, south = b, west = {b^{*}(k)}, west/style = {>->}, east = k, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, let us consider the subobject x := a^{*}(\ell ) \cap b^{*}(\ell ). Let \pi _{1} and \pi _{2} be the product projections of x.
Note that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} u_{1}\ell '\pi _{1} &= n\ell \ell '\pi _{1}\\ &= naa^{*}(\ell )\pi _{1} && \text {since $na = nb$}\\ &= nba^{*}(\ell )\pi _{1} && \text {since $a^{*}(\ell )\pi _{1} = x = b^{*}(\ell )\pi _{2}$}\\ &= nbb^{*}(\ell )\pi _{2}\\ &= n\ell \ell ''\pi _{2}\\ &= u_{1}\ell ''\pi _{2} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since u_{1} is monic, \ell '\pi _{1} = \ell ''\pi _{2}. Then
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} max &= maa^{*}(\ell )\pi _{1}\\ &= m\ell \ell '\pi _{1}\\ &= m\ell \ell ''\pi _{2}\\ &= mbb^{*}(\ell )\pi _{2}\\ &= mbx \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Analogously, the subobject a^{*}(k) \cap b^{*}(k) is also contained in e. Now, we show that y := a^{*}(\ell ) \cap b^{*}(k) is contained in e. The proof for a^{*}(k) \cap b^{*}(\ell ) is analogous to this one.
Let \nu _{1} and \nu _{2} be the product projections of y.
Then we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex:
egin {align*} u_{1}\ell '
u _{1} &= n\ell \ell '
u _{1}\ &= naa^{*}(\ell )
u _{1} && 	ext {since $na = nb$}\ &= nba^{*}(\ell )
u _{1}&& 	ext {since $a^{*}(\ell )
u _{1} = y = b^{*}(k)
u _{2}$}\ &= nbb^{*}(k)
u _{2}\ &= nkk''
u _{2}\ &= u_{2}k''
u _{2} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, \ell '\nu _{1} and k''\nu _{2} can be factored as follows:
This yields
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex:
egin {align*} may &= maa^{*}(\ell )
u _{1}\ &= m\ell \ell '
u _{1}\ &= m\ell i_{1}z\ &= fi_{1}z && 	ext {since $fi_{i} = gi_{2}$}\ &= gi_{2}z\ &= mki_{2}z\ &= mkk''
u _{2}\ &= mbb^{*}(k)
u _{2}\ &= mby \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may now conclude that n is an isomorphism. Then f can be factored as mn^{-1} u_{1} and g can be factored as mn^{-1} u_{2}. It remains to show uniqueness.

Let any two factors A_{1} \cup A_{2} \rightrightarrows B be given. Consider the equalizer \epsilon of these two factors. By definition, both u_{1} and u_{2} equalize these two factors, but this means that both u_{1} and u_{2} are contained in the subobject \epsilon . Thus, \epsilon is an isomorphism, so the two factors are equal.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be subobjects of A in a coherent category such that A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cong 0. Then A_{1} \cup A_{2} \cong A_{1} + A_{2}. Note that every coherent category has a (strict) initial object by .
By the following diagram is a pushout.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 0, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = {A_{1}}, se = {A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, north/style = {>->,exists}, west/style = {>->,exists}, south/style = {>->}, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: But, pushouts under 0 are coproducts.

A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f\colon A\to B and any subobject m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A, F\forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf {Sub}(FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.
Let \mathcal {C} be a Heyting category and the following square be a pullback in \mathcal {C}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {h^{*}}, west = {\forall _{f}}, south = {g^{*}}, east = {\forall _{k}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the corresponding left adjoint square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {\exists _{h}}, north/style = {<-}, west = {f^{*}}, west/style = {<-}, south = {\exists _{g}}, south/style = {<-}, east = {k^{*}}, east/style = {<-}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By , the two composites can be constructed as f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} and \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*} respectively. Since images commute with pullbacks in a regular category, we have f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g}. Then by the pasting lemma, f^{*}\Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}(m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf {Sub}(C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then both \forall _{k}h^{*} and g^{*}\forall _{f} are right adjoint to f^{*}\exists _{g}, so \forall _{k}h^{*} \cong g^{*}\forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.
Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

Fix a subobject m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) may be described as \exists _{m}m^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf {Sub}(A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}}\colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2})\to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f\colon B\to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {f^{*}(A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f^{*}\forall _{m}m^{*}(A_{2})\\ &\cong \forall _{n}g^{*}m^{*}(A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$}\\ &\cong \forall _{n}n^{*}f^{*}(A_{2})\\ &=: f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products. A (primitive) doctrine over \mathcal {C} is a \mathcal {C}-indexed category T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT}. If T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} and U\colon \mathcal {D}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} are primitive doctrines, then a morphism of doctrines F\colon T\to U consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A finite-product preserving functor F_{0}\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D}.
For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, a functor F_{1,X}\colon TX\to UF_{0}X.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the condition that for any morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TY, ne = {UF_{0}Y}, sw = TX, se = {UF_{0}X}, north = {F_{1,Y}}, south = {F_{1,X}}, west = {Tf}, east = {UF_{0}f}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Beck-Chevalley condition if, whenever there is a pullback shown below, we have f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{f}. Then this condition implies that f^{*}\Pi _{g} \cong \Pi _{h}k^{*} by the uniqueness of adjoint.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) has finite products \wedge and that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Frobenius reciprocity if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, objects \varphi \in T(X) and \psi \in T(Y), we have \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}\psi \wedge \varphi ) \cong \psi \wedge \Sigma _{f}(\varphi ).
A (first-order) hyperdoctrine is a doctrine T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} satisfying the following additional conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian closed and has finite coproducts.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits both a left adjoint \Sigma _{f} and a right adjoint \Pi _{f}.
T satisfies Beck-Chevalley.
T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism between hyperdoctrines F\colon T\to U is a morphisms between doctrines satisfying the additional condition that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following squares commute:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Sigma _{f}}, east = {\Sigma _{F_{0}f}}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Pi _{f}}, east = {\Pi _{F_{0}f}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite limits and T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a \mathcal {C}-indexed (pre-)lattice such that

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we can define a naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to T(X) for each object X \in \mathcal {C}. Moreover, for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}}, ne = {T(Y)}, sw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}}, se = {T(X)}, north = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y}}, south = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}}, west = {f^{*}}, east = {T(f)}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each object f\colon X\to Y in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, take {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} := \Sigma _{f}(1). To extend this assignment to a functor, it suffices to show that whenever there is a morphism \alpha \colon f\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(Y).

To this end, note that \alpha ^{*}(1) \leq \alpha ^{*}g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(X) because the unit of the adjunction \Sigma _{g} \dashv g^{*} gives 1 \leq g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Since \alpha ^{*}, as a right adjoint, preserves terminal objects and f^{*} \cong \alpha ^{*}g^{*} by the (pseudo)functoriality of T, we have 1 \leq f^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Then, the transpose along the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} yields {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}.
Now for each g\colon Z\to Y, form the following pullback:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = X, sw = Z, se = Y, north = {f^{*}(g)}, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley, we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} T(f){\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} &:= T(f)\Sigma _{g}(1)\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}k^{*}(1) && \text {right adjoint preserves terminal object}\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}(1)\\ &=: {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}f^{*}(g) \end {aligned}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These isomorphisms assemble into a natural isomorphism f^{*}{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \cong {\mathopen {}[f^{*}(\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})]\mathclose {}}_{X} since any two parallel morphisms in the preorder T(X) are equal.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with the structures listed in . Then T has comprehension schema if for each object X \in \mathcal {C} the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X} admits a right adjoint {\mathopen {}\{X\colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf {Sub}(A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal {C}. By , each f^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(X) is just \mathsf {Img}, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The internal language of \mathcal {C} consists of the signature \Sigma whose sorts are the objects of \mathcal {C}, function symbols are the morphisms of \mathcal {C}, and relation symbols are the subobjects in \mathcal {C}.

We write \mathcal {C} for the canonical \Sigma -structure that maps each variable to the appropriate product projection, each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B to its underlying morphism f\colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}\to B, and each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} to its underlying subobject R \rightarrowtail A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category.

fr:title.text: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The deduction system defined in is sound.

The first two structural rules are given by reflexivity and transitivity in each preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). The last structural rules is given by the action on morphisms of the functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta )\to \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
Every finite conjunction rule is given by the universal properties of terminal objects and binary products.

The first existential quantification rule is given by Frobenius reciprocity proven in . The second existential quantification rule is given by the transposition across the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

The first equality rule says the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(A) is contained in the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{A} with itself. Since the equalizer of the identity morphism with itself is an isomorphism (i.e., a maximal subobject of A), the soundness of this rule follows.
For the second equality rule, consider the following pullbacks. The right square is the pullback of \varphi along s.

Since s and t are equalized by the morphism s = t \rightarrowtail \Gamma , the outer square of the following diagram commutes. Thus, the intersection s = t \wedge \varphi {\mathopen {}[s]\mathclose {}} is contained in \varphi {\mathopen {}[t]\mathclose {}}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'
Total: x\colon A|\top \vdash \exists x\colon B.\mkern 5muR

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.

Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 3cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y)}, west = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} } \qquad \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y')}, west = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal {C} is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal {C} and m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} are inherited from \mathcal {C}.
An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.
Two sets are equal iff they have the same elements.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,y.\mkern 5mux = y \iff \forall z.\mkern 5muz \in x \iff z \in y

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The empty set \varnothing exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \exists x.\mkern 5mu\forall y.\mkern 5muy \notin x

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any two set x and y, the set \{x,y\} exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,y.\mkern 5mu\exists p.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in p \iff z = x \vee z = y

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a set x (of sets), the union \bigcup x exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x.\mkern 5mu\exists y.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \iff \exists v.\mkern 5muv \in x \wedge z \in v

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \varphi be any formula in the language of ZF set theory with free variables among x, z, p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n} and x be a set. The set \{z \in x \mid \varphi (x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n},z)\} exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n}.\mkern 5mu\exists y.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \iff z \in x \wedge \varphi (x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n},z)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any set x, the powerset P(x) is a set.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x.\mkern 5mu\exists p.\mkern 5mu\forall y.\mkern 5muy \in p \iff \forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \Rightarrow z \in x

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An inductive set exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \exists x.\mkern 5mu\varnothing \in x \wedge \forall y.\mkern 5muy \in x \Rightarrow y \cup \{y\} \in x

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be a \Sigma -structure in a category \mathcal {C} and \sigma = \Gamma |\varphi \vdash \psi be a sequent interpretable in \mathcal {C}. We say that \sigma is satisfied in M, denoted as M \models \sigma , if {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in the preorder \mathsf {Sub}(M(\Gamma )).

Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The internal language of \mathcal {C} consists of the signature \Sigma whose sorts are the objects of \mathcal {C}, function symbols are the morphisms of \mathcal {C}, and relation symbols are the subobjects in \mathcal {C}.

We write \mathcal {C} for the canonical \Sigma -structure that maps each variable to the appropriate product projection, each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B to its underlying morphism f\colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}\to B, and each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} to its underlying subobject R \rightarrowtail A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}.
A 2-functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between 2-categories is a strict functor.
A pseudofunctor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between bicategories is a lax functor in which the laxity constraints are 2-isomorphisms.
A strict functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between bicategories is a lax functor in which the laxity constraints are the identity 2-cells.
A 2-category is a bicategory in which the associators and the unitors are the identity 2-morphisms.
A bicategory consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of 0-cells A, B, C, etc.
A collection of 1-cells f, g, h, etc. Each 1-cell has a specified domain 0-cell and a codomain 0-cell.
A collection of 2-cells \alpha , \beta , \gamma , etc. Each 2-cell has a specified domain 1-cell and a codomain 1-cell.
For each 0-cell A, a specified identity 1-cell \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\to A.
For each 1-cell f\colon A\to B, a specified identity 2-cell \mathsf {id}_{f}\colon f\to f.
For any two composable 1-cells f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to C, a specified composite gf\colon A\to C.
For any two composable 2-cells \alpha \colon f\to g and \beta \colon g\to h, a specified vertical composite \beta \alpha \colon f\to h.
For any two 2-cells \alpha \colon f\to f' and \beta \colon g\to g' such that gf and g'f' are defined, a specified horizontal composite \beta * \alpha \colon gf\to g'f'.
For any triple of composable 1-cells f, g, and h, a specified 2-isomorphism a_{h,g,f}\colon (hg)f\to h(gf) called associator.
For any 1-cell f\colon A\to B, a specified 2-isomorphism \ell _{f}\colon \mathsf {id}_{B}f\to f called left unitor.
For any 1-cell f\colon A\to B, a specified 2-isomorphism r_{f}\colon f\mathsf {id}_{A}\to f called right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li:
For any 2-cell \alpha \colon f\to g, the following equations hold:
\mathsf {id}_{g}\alpha = \alpha
\alpha \mathsf {id}_{f} = \alpha
For any triple of vertically composable 2-cells \alpha , \beta , \gamma , the equation (\gamma \beta )\alpha = \gamma (\beta \alpha ) holds.
For any pair of composable 1-cells f and g, the equation \mathsf {id}_{g} * \mathsf {id}_{f} = \mathsf {id}_{gf} holds.

Law of middle four exchange: For any quadruple of 2-cells \alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta , the equation \alpha \gamma * \beta \delta = (\alpha * \beta )(\gamma * \delta ) holds whenever either side is defined.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The associator and unitors are required to satisfy the following additional coherence conditions:

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a functor. A morphism f\colon X\to Y in the domain category \mathcal {C} is said to be cartesian over a morphism u\colon I\to J in the codomain category \mathcal {D} if the following conditions are satisfied.

fr:ul.fr:li: Ff = u.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A comprehension category is a functor P\colon \mathcal {E}\to {\mathcal {B}}^{\to } such that the following conditions are satisfied.

fr:ul.fr:li: The composite \mathsf {cod} P\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {B} is a fibration.
P maps cartesian morphisms (w.r.t. \mathsf {cod} P) in \mathcal {E} to cartesian morphisms (w.r.t. \mathsf {cod}) in {\mathcal {B}}^{\to }, i.e., to pullback squares in \mathcal {B}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} is a fibration (or F is a fibered category over \mathcal {D}) if for every object Y \in \mathcal {C} and morphism u\colon I\to FY in \mathcal {D}, there is a cartesian morphism f above u.

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be bicategories. We write a, \ell , r for the associator, left unitor, and right unitor of \mathcal {C} respectively and we use the primed version of these symbols for the corresponding structures in \mathcal {D}.
A lax functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: Action on 0-cells: Each 0-cell A in \mathcal {C} is mapped to a specified 0-cell FA in \mathcal {D}.
Action on 1-cells: Each 1-cell f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} is mapped to a specified 1-cell Ff\colon FA\to FB in \mathcal {D}.
Action on 2-cells: Each 2-cell \alpha \colon f\to g in \mathcal {C} is mapped to a specified 2-cell F\alpha \colon Ff\to Fg in \mathcal {D}.
Lax functoriality constraint: For any pair of composable 1-cells g, f in \mathcal {C}, a specified 2-cell F^{2}_{g,f}\colon FgFf\to F(gf) in \mathcal {D}.
Lax unity constraint: For any 0-cell A in \mathcal {C}, a specified 2-cell F^{0}_{A}\colon \mathsf {id}_{FA}\to F(\mathsf {id}_{A}) in \mathcal {D}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: For any 1-cell f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C}, the equation F(\mathsf {id}_{f}) = \mathsf {id}_{Ff} holds.
For any vertically composable 2-cells \alpha , \beta in \mathcal {C}, the equation F(\beta \alpha ) = F\beta F\alpha holds.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The laxity constraints are subject to the following additional conditions:

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Beck-Chevalley condition if, whenever there is a pullback shown below, we have f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{f}. Then this condition implies that f^{*}\Pi _{g} \cong \Pi _{h}k^{*} by the uniqueness of adjoint.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} be a doctrine. Suppose that for each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) has finite products \wedge and that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Frobenius reciprocity if for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, objects \varphi \in T(X) and \psi \in T(Y), we have \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}\psi \wedge \varphi ) \cong \psi \wedge \Sigma _{f}(\varphi ).
A (first-order) hyperdoctrine is a doctrine T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} satisfying the following additional conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian closed and has finite coproducts.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits both a left adjoint \Sigma _{f} and a right adjoint \Pi _{f}.
T satisfies Beck-Chevalley.
T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism between hyperdoctrines F\colon T\to U is a morphisms between doctrines satisfying the additional condition that for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following squares commute:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Sigma _{f}}, east = {\Sigma _{F_{0}f}}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = TX, ne = {UF_{0}X}, sw = TY, se = {UF_{0}Y}, north = {F_{1,X}}, south = {F_{1,Y}}, west = {\Pi _{f}}, east = {\Pi _{F_{0}f}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with the structures listed in . Then T has comprehension schema if for each object X \in \mathcal {C} the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X} admits a right adjoint {\mathopen {}\{X\colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products. A (primitive) doctrine over \mathcal {C} is a \mathcal {C}-indexed category T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT}. If T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} and U\colon \mathcal {D}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {CAT} are primitive doctrines, then a morphism of doctrines F\colon T\to U consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A finite-product preserving functor F_{0}\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D}.
For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, a functor F_{1,X}\colon TX\to UF_{0}X.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the condition that for any morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = TY, ne = {UF_{0}Y}, sw = TX, se = {UF_{0}X}, north = {F_{1,Y}}, south = {F_{1,X}}, west = {Tf}, east = {UF_{0}f}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An axiomatization of a theory \mathscr {T} over a signature \Sigma is a collection of sequents over \Sigma . These sequents are the (non-logical) axioms of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr {T}.
Let h\colon M\to N be a homomorphism between \Sigma -structures in a Heyting category \mathcal {C}.

fr:ul.fr:li: The homomorphism h is called an embedding (alternatively, M is a substructure of N) if the square above is a pullback for all atomic formulas.
The homomorphism h is called an elementary embedding if the square above is a pullback for all first-order formulas.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a term-in-context \Gamma .t of sort B in M is a morphism {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}\colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})\to MB defined recursively on the structure of t as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .x_{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the i-th projection \pi _{i}\colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})\to MB_{i}.

If f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is a function symbol and t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n} are terms of appropriate sorts then {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .f(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n})\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the composite M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) \xrightarrow {({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t_{1}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .t_{n}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M})} M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) \xrightarrow {Mf} MB

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1}\colon B_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma . Given a \Sigma -structure M in \mathcal {C}, the interpretation of a formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi in M is a subobject {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) defined recursively on the structure of \varphi as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\top \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \wedge \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the intersection of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \vee \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the union of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \Rightarrow \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting implication {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \Rightarrow {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\lnot \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the Heyting negation of {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the image of the following composite: {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \rightarrowtail M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A) \xrightarrow {\pi } M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) where \pi is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is \forall _{\pi }({\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma ,x\colon A.\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M}), where \forall _{\pi } is the right adjoint associated with a Heyting category and \pi \colon M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m},A)\to M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m}) is the projection of the first m factors.

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary union of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

{\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} is the arbitrary intersection of each {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi _{i}\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in \mathsf {Sub}(M(B_{1},\ldots ,B_{m})).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be a \Sigma -structure in a category \mathcal {C}. Fix an axiomatization of a theory \mathscr {T} interpretable in \mathcal {C}. Then M is a model of \mathscr {T}, denoted as M \vDash \mathscr {T}, if every axiom of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr {T} is satisfied.

The category \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C}) is the full subcategory of \Sigma \text {-}\mathsf {Str}(\mathcal {C}) spanned by the models of \mathscr {T}, and the category \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C})_{e} has the same objects as \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C}) but the morphisms are all elementary morphisms.

A context is a finite list of distinct variables. Recall that each variable has a specified sort. A context is said to be suitable for a formula (resp., term) if every free variable of that formula (resp., term) appears in the given context.
A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi , where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi .

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products and \Sigma be a signature. The category of \Sigma -structures in \mathcal {C}, denoted as \Sigma \text {-}\mathsf {Str}(\mathcal {C}), consists of the following data:

html:tr.html:td:
A \Sigma -structure consists of the following data:
Each sort A in \Sigma is associated with an object MA in \mathcal {C}. This is extended to any finite string of sorts by the assignment M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) \mapsto MA_{1} \times \cdots \times MA_{n}. The empty string is associated with the terminal object 1 of \mathcal {C}.
Each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is associated with a morphism Mf\colon M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n})\to MB in \mathcal {C}.
Each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} is associated with a subobject of M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) in \mathcal {C}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Composition and identities are defined componentwise from those in \mathcal {C}.
The collection of infinitary first-order formulas over a signature \Sigma is defined inductively by the following rules:

fr:ol.fr:li: For each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} and terms t_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}\colon A_{n}, R(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}) is a formula.
For any two terms of the same sort s,t\colon A, s = t is a formula.
\top is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \wedge \psi is a formula.
\bot is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \vee \psi is a formula.
If \varphi and \psi are formulas, then \varphi \Rightarrow \psi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula, then \lnot \varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If \varphi is a formula and x\colon A is a variable, then \forall x\colon A.\mkern 5mu\varphi is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigvee _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.
If I is a set and for each i \in I, \varphi _{i} is a formula, then \bigwedge _{i \in I}\varphi _{i} is a formula.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Fragments of this collection are defined as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: The collection of atomic formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 and 2.
The collection of Horn formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4.
The collection of regular formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 4 and 9.
The collection of coherent formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6 and 9.
The collection of first-order formulas over \Sigma is inductive generated by 1 through 10.
The collection of geometric formulas over \Sigma is inductively generated by 1 through 6, 9, and 11.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (first-order) signature \Sigma consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of sorts.

A collection of function symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n},B are sorts. Unary (n = 0) function symbols are also called constant symbols.

A collection of relation symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} where A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} are sorts. Unary (n = 0) relation symbols are usually called atomic propositions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Each sort comes with a collection of variables. We assume that given any collection of variables of sort A, there is a variable of sort A not in the given collection.
Let \Sigma be a signature. The collection of (raw) terms over \Sigma is inductively generated by the following rules:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each variable x of sort A is a term of sort A.

Let us write t\colon A if t is a term of sort A. If f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is a function symbol and t_{1}\colon A_{1},\ldots ,t_{n}\colon A_{n} are terms of corresponding sorts, then f(t_{1},\ldots ,t_{n})\colon B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products. \mathcal {C} is said to be cartesian closed if every object is exponentiable.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products. An object A is said to be exponentiable if the functor A \times (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) admits a right adjoint (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{A}.

Let A' \rightarrowtail A be a subobject. The pseudocomplement of A', denoted as {A'}^{\circ }, is the largest subobject of A disjoint from A', i.e., A' \cap {A'}^{\circ } is the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A). Further, a pseudocomplement is a complement if A' \cup {A'}^{\circ } \cong A, i.e., A' \cup {A'}^{\circ } is the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A).
A quasitopos is a locally cartesian closed, cocartesian category equipped with a weak subobject classifier.

A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f\colon A\to B and any subobject m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A, F\forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf {Sub}(FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.
Let \mathcal {C} be a category. A coproduct A + B is said to be disjoint if the injections A \to A + B and B \to A + B are monic and their intersection is an initial object of \mathsf {Sub}(A + B).
A coherent category is said to be positive if it has disjoint finite coproducts.
A pretopos is an effective and positive coherent category.

A regular category \mathcal {C} is said to be coherent if each \mathsf {Sub}(B) has finite unions and each f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) preserves them. A coherent functor between coherent categories is a regular functor which preserves finite unions.
Let \mathcal {C} be a category with an initial object 0. The initial object 0 is said to be strict if every morphism with codomain 0 is an isomorphism.
A quantale is a semigroup object in the monoidal category of suplattices.

An epimorphism f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m\colon C\rightarrowtail B and any morphism g\colon A\to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).

A category \mathcal {C} is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf {Sub}(A) \hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) for all objects A \in \mathcal {C}.
A category \mathcal {C} is said to be locally cartesian if for any object A \in \mathcal {C}, the slice {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} is cartesian.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal {C} is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal {C} and m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} are inherited from \mathcal {C}.

Let B be an object in a category \mathcal {C}. A subobject of B is a monomorphism m\colon A \rightarrowtail B. The category of subobjects of B, denoted as \mathsf {Sub}(B), is the full subcategory of {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} spanned by monomorphisms.
A (Lawvere-Tierney) topology on a topos \mathcal {E} is a morphism j\colon \Omega \to \Omega satisfying the following equations.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-closed if its closure is isomorphic to itself.
Let j be a topology on a topos. Let m\colon A \rightarrowtail B be a subobject. The j-closure of m is the subobject classified by j\chi _{m}\colon B \to \Omega .
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-dense if its closure is an isomorphism.

An equivalence relation in a cartesian category is said to be effective if it is the kernel pair of some morphism. An effective category is a cartesian category in which every equivalence relation is effective.
Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. The relation (a,b) is said to be reflexive if it contains the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A\rightarrowtail A \times A, i.e., if there is a morphism \rho \colon A\to R such that a\rho = \mathsf {id}_{A} and b\rho = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal {E}. An object S \in \mathcal {E} is said to be j-separated if for any dense subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f\colon A \to S, there is at most one morphism g\colon B \to S such that f = gm.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal {E}. An object S \in \mathcal {E} is said to be a j-sheaf if for any dense subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f\colon A \to S, there is exactly one morphism g\colon B \to S such that f = gm.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be symmetric if it contains the twisted relation (b,a)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A, i.e., if there is a morphism \sigma \colon R\to R such that a\sigma = b and b\sigma = a.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a cartesian category. (a,b) is said to be transitive if it contains the relation (ap,bq)\colon R \times _{A} R\rightarrowtail A \times A, where p and q are given in the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {R \times _{A} R}, ne = R, sw = R, se = A, nw/style = pullback, north = q, west = p, south = b, east = a, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, (a,b) is transitive if there is a morphism \tau \colon R \times _{A} R\to R such that a\tau = ap and b\tau = bq.
The following diagram commutes.
An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.
A geometric morphism f\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is said to be essential if its inverse image f^{*} admits a left adjoint.
Let \mathcal {E} and \mathcal {F} be topoi. A geometric morphism f\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is an adjoint pair of functors
such that f^{*} is left exact. The functors f_{*} and f^{*} are called the direct image and the inverse image respectively.
Let f,g\colon \mathcal {E}\rightrightarrows \mathcal {F} be a pair of geometric morphisms. A geometric transformation \alpha \colon f\to g is a natural transformation \alpha \colon f_{*}\to g_{*}.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 1_{\mathcal {D}} \otimes FX, sw = F1_{\mathcal {C}} \otimes FX, se = F(1_{\mathcal {C}} \otimes X), ne = FX, east = F\lambda _{\mathcal {C}}, west = \phi ^{1} \otimes FX, north = \lambda _{\mathcal {D}}, south = \phi ^{2}_{1_{\mathcal {C}},X}, height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {E} and \mathcal {F} be topoi. A logical functor F\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is a functor preserving finite limits, exponentials, and the subobject classifier.
A monoidal category consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: An underlying category \mathcal {C}.
A functor \otimes \colon \mathcal {C} \times \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {C} called the monoidal product.
An object 1 \in \mathcal {C} called the monoidal unit.
A natural isomorphism \alpha _{{X},{Y},{Z}} \colon (X \otimes Y) \otimes Z\to X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) called the associator.
A natural isomorphism \lambda _{X}\colon 1 \otimes X\to X called the left unitor.
A natural isomorphism \rho _{X}\colon X \otimes 1\to X called the right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes 1) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes (1 \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{Y}, west = \rho _{X} \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{{X},{1},{Y}} , south/style = {double}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality \lambda _{1} = \rho _{1}\colon 1 \otimes 1\to 1 holds.
The following diagram commutes.
Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be monoidal categories. A monoidal functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: An underlying functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D}.
A natural transformation \phi ^{2}_{X,Y}\colon FX \otimes FY\to F(X \otimes Y).
A morphism \phi ^{1}\colon 1_{\mathcal {D}}\to F1_{\mathcal {C}}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 1_{\mathcal {D}} \otimes FX, sw = F1_{\mathcal {C}} \otimes FX, se = F(1_{\mathcal {C}} \otimes X), ne = FX, east = F\lambda _{\mathcal {C}}, west = \phi ^{1} \otimes FX, north = \lambda _{\mathcal {D}}, south = \phi ^{2}_{1_{\mathcal {C}},X}, height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = FX \otimes 1_{\mathcal {D}}, sw = FX \otimes F1_{\mathcal {C}}, se = F(X \otimes 1_{\mathcal {C}}), ne = FX, east = F\rho _{\mathcal {C}}, west = FX \otimes \phi ^{1}, north = \rho _{\mathcal {D}}, south = \phi ^{2}_{X,1_{\mathcal {C}}}, height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following diagram commutes.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = FX \otimes 1_{\mathcal {D}}, sw = FX \otimes F1_{\mathcal {C}}, se = F(X \otimes 1_{\mathcal {C}}), ne = FX, east = F\rho _{\mathcal {C}}, west = FX \otimes \phi ^{1}, north = \rho _{\mathcal {D}}, south = \phi ^{2}_{X,1_{\mathcal {C}}}, height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monoidal category is said to be strict if \alpha , \lambda , and \rho are all identities.
A monoidal functor is said to be strict if \phi ^{2} and \phi ^{1} are identities.
A monoidal functor is said to be strong if \phi ^{2} and \phi ^{1} are isomorphisms.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes 1) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes (1 \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{Y}, west = \rho _{X} \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{{X},{1},{Y}} , south/style = {double}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality \lambda _{1} = \rho _{1}\colon 1 \otimes 1\to 1 holds.

fr:title.text: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a cover iff \mathcal {C} satisfies y\colon B|\top \vdash \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y in its internal language.
Suppose that f is a cover. Let e = (b,a)\colon E\to B \times A be the interpretation of f(x) = y in \mathcal {C}. Note that a is an isomorphism since the following is also an equalizer diagram.
By , {\mathopen {}\llbracket y\colon B.\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of the following composite.
By assumption, fa = b. Thus, the image of b coincides with that of fa.
Since a is an isomorphism, it follows that the image of f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(b). Thus, \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism.
Assume the converse. Then the identity morphism factors through \mathsf {Img}(b), i.e., \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism. Thus, it follows that f is a cover.

fr:title.text: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to C is the composite of g\colon A\to B and h\colon B\to C iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = h(g(x)) in its internal language.

Suppose that f = hg. Then {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket h\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket g\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = hg and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = f. Thus, the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the terminal object, and the result follows immediately.

Suppose the converse. Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Thus, it follows that f = hg.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a monomorphism iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x,x'\colon A|f(x) = f(x') \vdash x = x' in its internal language.

Suppose that f is monic. Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail A \times A be the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{1} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{2}. Then it follows that f\pi _{1}e = f\pi _{2}e. Since f is monic, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e. Then it follows that e factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket x = x'\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}.
Assume the converse. Suppose that fu = fv for some parallel pair of morphisms u,v\colon C\rightrightarrows A. Then it follows that (u,v) factors through e.
Thus, u = \pi _{1}(u,v) = \pi _{1}ew and v = \pi _{2}(u,v) = \pi _{2}ew. By assumption, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e so u = v.

fr:title.text: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to A is the identity morphism iff x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = x is satisfied in the internal language of \mathcal {C}.

Suppose that f is the identity morphism. Then by , {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is \mathsf {id}_{A} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. But the equalizer with itself is the terminal object. Thus, \top \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} in \mathsf {Sub}(A) as required.

Conversely, suppose that the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) (i.e., the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A}) factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Then it follows that \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Since {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = \mathsf {id}_{A} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f, it follows that f = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with those structures listed in . Additionally, assume that T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity. Then there is a doctrine T^{\flat }\colon \mathsf {Elts}(T)^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} indexed by the syntactic category of T such that T^{\flat } admits comprehension schema.
This proof is adopted from Errol Yuksel's proof. Any error should be attributed to me.

Let us define the action on objects by T^{\flat }(\Gamma .\varphi ) = {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}}. That is, T^{\flat } sends each formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi to its downward closure ordered by entailment. By assumption, each T(\Gamma ) is cartesian. Thus, each slice {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}} is also cartesian by .
For each morphism f\colon \Gamma .\varphi \to \Delta .\psi , we define T^{\flat }(f) to be the following composite:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: {{T(\Delta )}_{/{\psi }}} \xrightarrow {{{T(f)}_{/{\psi }}}} {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{T(f)(\psi )}}} \xrightarrow {\varphi \wedge \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}} {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: where {{T(f)}_{/{\psi }}} sends each \chi \vdash \psi to T(f)(\chi ) \vdash T(f)(\psi ) and \varphi \wedge \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}} is the usual pullback functor along the morphism \varphi \vdash T(f)(\psi ).
This composite admits a left adjoint \exists ^{\flat }_{f} defined as the composite of the top morphisms of the following diagram:
where \Sigma _{\varphi } is the left adjoint in and {{\Sigma _{f}}_{/{\psi }}} is the functor given by the action on morphisms of the left adjoint \Sigma _{f} \dashv T(f).
Let \Gamma |\chi \vdash \varphi . And assume the following pullback square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = \Gamma '.(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(h)(\psi ')), nw/style = {pullback}, ne = \Delta '.\psi ', sw = \Gamma .\varphi , se = \Delta .\psi , north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We wish to show that T^{\flat }(f)\exists ^{\flat }_{g}(\chi ) \cong \exists ^{\flat }_{h}T^{\flat }(k)(\chi ). The left-hand side computes to \psi ' \wedge T(f){{\Sigma _{g}}_{/{\psi }}}(\chi ), while the right-hand side computes to {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{g}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(h)(\psi ') \wedge T(k)(\chi )). This is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(k)(\chi )) by Frobenius reciprocity. T(k), as a right adjoint, commutes with pullbacks. Thus, the right-hand side is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\varphi \wedge \chi ). Further, since \chi \vdash \psi , this is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\chi ). Then, \exists ^{\flat }_{f} inherits the Beck-Chevalley condition from \Sigma _{f}.

Since T^{\flat } has all the structures listed in , it admits a naming functor. Let us define {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}\colon T^{\flat }(\Gamma .\varphi )\to {{\mathsf {Elts}(T)}_{/{\Gamma .\varphi }}} by
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \chi \vdash \varphi \}\mathclose {}} := (\mathsf {id}_{\Gamma }, \chi \vdash \varphi )
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \gamma \colon \Delta .\chi \to \Gamma .\varphi and \psi \in T(\Gamma ) such that \psi \vdash \varphi . Then {\mathopen {}[\gamma ]\mathclose {}}_{\Gamma .\varphi } \leq \psi iff \exists _{\gamma }(\chi ) \leq \psi iff \chi \leq T^{\flat }(\gamma )(\psi ) iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). But there is a morphism \gamma \to {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \psi \vdash \varphi \}\mathclose {}} iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). Thus,
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{\Gamma .\varphi } \dashv {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'
Total: x\colon A|\top \vdash \exists x\colon B.\mkern 5muR

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.

Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 3cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y)}, west = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} } \qquad \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y')}, west = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.

fr:title.text: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The deduction system defined in is sound.

The first two structural rules are given by reflexivity and transitivity in each preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). The last structural rules is given by the action on morphisms of the functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta )\to \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
Every finite conjunction rule is given by the universal properties of terminal objects and binary products.

The first existential quantification rule is given by Frobenius reciprocity proven in . The second existential quantification rule is given by the transposition across the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

The first equality rule says the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(A) is contained in the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{A} with itself. Since the equalizer of the identity morphism with itself is an isomorphism (i.e., a maximal subobject of A), the soundness of this rule follows.
For the second equality rule, consider the following pullbacks. The right square is the pullback of \varphi along s.

Since s and t are equalized by the morphism s = t \rightarrowtail \Gamma , the outer square of the following diagram commutes. Thus, the intersection s = t \wedge \varphi {\mathopen {}[s]\mathclose {}} is contained in \varphi {\mathopen {}[t]\mathclose {}}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite limits and T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a \mathcal {C}-indexed (pre-)lattice such that

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we can define a naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to T(X) for each object X \in \mathcal {C}. Moreover, for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}}, ne = {T(Y)}, sw = {{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}}, se = {T(X)}, north = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y}}, south = {{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}}, west = {f^{*}}, east = {T(f)}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each object f\colon X\to Y in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, take {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} := \Sigma _{f}(1). To extend this assignment to a functor, it suffices to show that whenever there is a morphism \alpha \colon f\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(Y).

To this end, note that \alpha ^{*}(1) \leq \alpha ^{*}g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(X) because the unit of the adjunction \Sigma _{g} \dashv g^{*} gives 1 \leq g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Since \alpha ^{*}, as a right adjoint, preserves terminal objects and f^{*} \cong \alpha ^{*}g^{*} by the (pseudo)functoriality of T, we have 1 \leq f^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Then, the transpose along the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} yields {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}.
Now for each g\colon Z\to Y, form the following pullback:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = X, sw = Z, se = Y, north = {f^{*}(g)}, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley, we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} T(f){\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} &:= T(f)\Sigma _{g}(1)\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}k^{*}(1) && \text {right adjoint preserves terminal object}\\ &\cong \Sigma _{f^{*}(g)}(1)\\ &=: {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}f^{*}(g) \end {aligned}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These isomorphisms assemble into a natural isomorphism f^{*}{\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \cong {\mathopen {}[f^{*}(\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})]\mathclose {}}_{X} since any two parallel morphisms in the preorder T(X) are equal.

fr:title.text: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf {Sub}(A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal {C}. By , each f^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(X) is just \mathsf {Img}, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.
Let \mathcal {C} be a cartesian category. Then an object B is exponentiable iff B^{*}\colon \mathcal {C}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}.
Note that pullbacks over the terminal object 1 are products. Thus, we may assume that B^{*} sends each object A \in \mathcal {C} to the first projection B \times A \to B.

Suppose that B^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}. B \times (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) can be expressed as \Sigma _{B}B^{*}, where \Sigma _{B} is constructed in . By , \Sigma _{B} is left adjoint to B^{*}. Thus, we may define (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{B} := \Pi _{B}B^{*}.

Conversely, suppose that B is exponentiable. Let us use the notation (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{\dag } to denote the exponential transpose. Then given any object f\colon A\to B in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, let \Pi _{B}f be given by the following pullback, where \pi _{1}\colon B \times 1\to B is the product projection.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\Pi _{B}f}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A^{B}}, sw = 1, se = {B^{B}}, north = \beta , east = {f^{B}}, south = {\pi _{1}^{\dag }}, west = {\mathsf {!}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now let \alpha \colon f\to g be a morphism in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, we extend the above assignment to morphisms as follows:
Note that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} g^{B}\alpha ^{B}\beta &= (g\alpha )^{B}\beta && \text {functoriality of $(\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{B}$}\\ &= f^{B}\beta \\ &= \pi _{1}^{\dag }\mathsf {!} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let any morphism \alpha \colon B^{*}(A')\to f be given.
Then this morphism corresponds to a unique morphism A' \to \Pi _{B}f as follows:
The unit and counit of the adjunction can be extracted from the square above.

Let \mathcal {C} be a cartesian category. If A is exponentiable in \mathcal {C} then so is B^{*}(A) in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} for any object B \in \mathcal {C}. Moreover, the pullback functor B^{*} preserves any exponential that exists in \mathcal {C}.
For each object f\colon C\to B in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, let us define the action on objects of (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{B^{*}(A)} by the following pullback square:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = D, nw/style = pullback, ne = {C^{A}}, sw = B, se = {B^{A}}, east = {f^{A}}, south = {\pi _{2}^{\dag }}, west = {f^{B^{*}(A)}}, north = \beta , }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: where \pi _{2}^{\dag } is the exponential transpose of the projection \pi _{2}\colon A \times B\to B.
Let \alpha \colon f\to g be a morphism in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. The above assignment can be extended to an action on morphisms by the universal property of pullbacks:
The unit and the counit can be defined by the following commutative squares:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = D, nw/style = pullback, ne = {C^{A}}, sw = B, se = {B^{A}}, north = {\varepsilon _{f}^{\dag }}, west = {f^{B^{*}(A)}}, south = {\pi _{2}^{\dag }}, east = {f^{A}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that B^{*}(A) \times f^{B^{*}(A)} is the diagonal of the following pullback square:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A \times D}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {D}, sw = {A \times B}, se = B, west = {\mathsf {id}_{A} \times f^{B^{*}(A)}}, south = {\pi _{2}}, east = {f^{B^{*}(A)}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The second half of the statement follows immediately from the first half.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

Fix a subobject m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) may be described as \exists _{m}m^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf {Sub}(A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}}\colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2})\to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f\colon B\to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {f^{*}(A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f^{*}\forall _{m}m^{*}(A_{2})\\ &\cong \forall _{n}g^{*}m^{*}(A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$}\\ &\cong \forall _{n}n^{*}f^{*}(A_{2})\\ &=: f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a Heyting category and the following square be a pullback in \mathcal {C}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {h^{*}}, west = {\forall _{f}}, south = {g^{*}}, east = {\forall _{k}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the corresponding left adjoint square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {\exists _{h}}, north/style = {<-}, west = {f^{*}}, west/style = {<-}, south = {\exists _{g}}, south/style = {<-}, east = {k^{*}}, east/style = {<-}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By , the two composites can be constructed as f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} and \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*} respectively. Since images commute with pullbacks in a regular category, we have f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g}. Then by the pasting lemma, f^{*}\Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}(m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf {Sub}(C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then both \forall _{k}h^{*} and g^{*}\forall _{f} are right adjoint to f^{*}\exists _{g}, so \forall _{k}h^{*} \cong g^{*}\forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be an effective equivalence relation in a regular category. Then a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A admit a coequalizer d. Moreover, (a,b) is a kernel pair of d.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, (a,b) is a kernel pair of some morphism. Then the result follows immediately from .

fr:title.text: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, every kernel pair has a coequalizer. Moreover, the given kernel pair is also a kernel pair of the coequalizer.

Let a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a morphism f\colon A\to B. Consider the cover-mono factorization of f: f = f_{m}f_{c}. By , it suffices to show that (a,b) is a kernel pair of f_{c}, i.e., the following diagram is a pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = R, ne = A, sw = A, se = {\mathsf {Img}(f)}, north = b, west = a, south = {f_{c}}, south/style = {cover}, east = {f_{c}}, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, the diagram commutes since fa = f_{m}f_{c}a = f_{m}f_{c}b = fb by definition, and f_{m} is monic. Let h,k\colon C\rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms such that f_{c}h = f_{c}k. Then f_{m}f_{c}h = fh = fk = f_{m}f_{c}k. Thus, the unique factor is given by the following pullback.

fr:title.text: Every monomorphism is regular in a pretopos

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every monomorphism is regular in a pretopos
